    Alternate Page for Screenreader Users

        Subject Guides
       </a>

      <span id="bc_guide_name">
       Disease and Medicine in American History
      </span>
     </div>
    </div>
    <div id="guide_header_title">
     <h1>
      <span class="guidetitle">
       Disease and Medicine in American History &nbsp;
      </span>
     </h1>
    </div>
    <div class="guideattr" id="guideattr">
     <span id="lastupdate" class="lastupdate">
      Last Updated: May 15, 2014
     </span>
     <span class="guideurl">
      URL: http://libraryguides.muhlenberg.edu/diseasemedhist
     </span>
     <span class="printguideurl" style="padding:0px 10px 0px 10px;">
      <span class="iprint">
       <a href="/print_content.php?pid=559320&amp;sid=4610077&amp;mode=g" title="View in a format suitable for printers and screen readers">
        Print Guide
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span class="rssupdatelink" style="padding:0px 10px; border-left:dotted thin #666666;">
      <span class="irss">
       <a href="#" onclick="return showDlg('RSS Updates','/process_content.php?m=rssupdates&amp;iid=3322&amp;pid=559320&amp;sid=4610077&amp;gid=0&amp;uid=95550',0)" title="Subscribe to Updates via RSS">
        RSS Updates
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </div>

       </td>
       <td align="right" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        <span class="lgsearch">

    <div id="commentslistp4610077" style="display:none; margin:0px 10px;">

    <div id="content">
     <div id="contentleft" style="width:230px;">
      <div id="leftboxes">
       <div id="wrapbox16949121">
        <div class="roundbox outerbox" id="16949121">
         <div class="roundbox headerbox" id="title16949121">
          <div class="bi_links">
           &nbsp;
          </div>
          <h2>
           Need help with your research?
          </h2>
         </div>
         <div class="roundbox innerbox innerbox_3" id="content16949121">
          <p>
           Contact:
          </p>
          <p>
           <br />
           Kelly Cannon
           <br />
           Humanities &amp; Business Librarian
           <br />
           phone: x3602
           <br />
           email: kcannon@muhlenberg.edu
          </p>
          <div id="boxatt16949121" class="boxatt">
           <div class="itemlist">
            <ul>
            </ul>
            &nbsp;&nbsp;
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div id="wrapbox16949210">
        <div class="roundbox outerbox" id="16949210">
         <div class="roundbox headerbox" id="title16949210">
          <div class="bi_links">
           &nbsp;
          </div>
          <h2>
           Evaluating web sites
          </h2>
         </div>
         <div class="roundbox innerbox innerbox_3" id="content16949210">
          <p>
           Selected criteria:
          </p>
          <p style="padding-left: 30px;">
           Authority of site source/host
           <br />
           Legibility of document
           <br />
           Accuracy of document
           <br />
           Editor's notes
           <br />
           Descriptive notes
           <br />
           Maintenance
           <br />
           Contact information
           <br />
           Meets expectations
           <br />
           Substantive content
          </p>
          <p>
           Two sites that meet many or all of these criteria are
           <a href="http://unitproj.library.ucla.edu/biomed/his/painexhibit/">
            Relief of Pain and Suffering
           </a>
           , an exhibit sponsored by the libraries of UCLA, and
           <a href="http://www.tlcarchive.org/htm/home.htm">
            The Living City
           </a>
           , a medical history project at Columbia University.
          </p>
          <div id="boxatt16949210" class="boxatt">
           <div class="itemlist">
            <ul>
            </ul>
            &nbsp;&nbsp;
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div id="contentcenter" style="width:520px;padding-left:0px; margin-left:0px; margin-right:8px; float:left;">
      <div id="centerboxes">
       <div id="wrapbox16949129">
        <div class="roundbox outerbox" id="16949129">
         <div class="roundbox headerbox" id="title16949129">
          <div class="bi_links">
           &nbsp;
          </div>
          <h2>
           Recommended search directories
          </h2>
         </div>
         <div class="roundbox innerbox innerbox_3" id="content16949129">
          <p>
           To find rated web sites, try web directories like
           <a href="http://lii.org">
            Librarian's Index to the Internet
           </a>
           and
           <a href="http://www.intute.ac.uk/">
            Intute
           </a>
           .
           <br />
           <br />
           <strong>
            Tip:
           </strong>
           Because these directories are highly selective, cast a wide net. Search on broad terms: "epidemic" or "influenza" or "epidemic and history."
          </p>
          <div id="boxatt16949129" class="boxatt">
           <div class="itemlist">
            <ul>
            </ul>
            &nbsp;&nbsp;
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div id="wrapbox16949384">
        <div class="roundbox outerbox" id="16949384">
         <div class="roundbox headerbox" id="title16949384">
          <div class="bi_links">
           &nbsp;
          </div>
          <h2>
           Sites that contain primary historical documents relating to medical history in America
          </h2>
         </div>
         <div class="roundbox innerbox innerbox_3" id="content16949384">
          <p>
           The National Library of Medicine is a good starting point, providing reliable primary documentation in the form of
           <a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/hmd/ihm/">
            Images from the History of Medicine
           </a>
           and
           <a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/projects/bydate.html">
            Exhibitions in the History of Medicine
           </a>
           . Another highly recommended site for its scholarship and searchability is the
           <a href="http://jeffline.tju.edu/archives/phdil/phdil.html">
            Philadelphia Historical Digital Image Library
           </a>
           . See also the
           <a href="http://phil.cdc.gov/Phil/home.asp">
            Public Health Image Library
           </a>
           sponsored by the Centers for Disease Control. The Library of Congress also has
           <a href="http://lcweb2.loc.gov/pp/mdbquery.html">
            Prints and Photographs Online Catalog
           </a>
           , though the images on the screen may be too small for immediate viewing. A site containing thousands of primary texts and images on disability is the
           <a href="http://www.disabilitymuseum.org/">
            Disability History Museum
           </a>
           .
           <br />
           <br />
           Additionally look at the
           <a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/hmd/breath/breathhome.html">
            Breath of Life Exhibit
           </a>
           , the
           <a href="http://www.swsbm.com/homepage/">
            Southwest School of Botanical Medicine
           </a>
           , and the
           <a href="http://www.utoledo.edu/library/canaday/exhibits/quackery/quack1.html">
            Emergence of Modern Medicine in 19th Century America
           </a>
           <br />
           <br />
           Epidemics receive some attention in this directory. See the
           <a href="http://www.uab.edu/reynolds/cholera.html">
            Cholera Epidemic of 1873
           </a>
           and
           <a href="http://www.hsl.virginia.edu/historical/medical_history/yellow_fever/">
            Yellow Fever and the Reed Commission
           </a>
           .
           <br />
           <br />
           The premier locator for primary documents in American history is
           <a href="http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/index.html">
            American Memory
           </a>
           , sponsored by the Library of Congress. Search by keyword, and limit to desired format or collection. A simple search on "medicine" brings up many documents on a variety of diseases and treatments from earlier times.
          </p>
          <div id="boxatt16949384" class="boxatt">
           <div class="itemlist">
            <ul>
            </ul>
            &nbsp;&nbsp;
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div id="wrapbox16949515">
        <div class="roundbox outerbox" id="16949515">
         <div class="roundbox headerbox" id="title16949515">
          <div class="bi_links">
           &nbsp;
          </div>
          <h2>
           Magazines and newspapers as primary sources
          </h2>
         </div>
         <div class="roundbox innerbox innerbox_3" id="content16949515">
          <p>
           <strong>
            Poole's index to periodical literature
           </strong>
           , 1882-1908 (Index shelves, Level A) and
           <strong>
            Readers' guide to periodical literature
           </strong>
           , 1900-1997 (Index shelves, Level A) index U.S. magazines, some of which will be held in Trexler Library. Consult the guide
           <strong>
            Trexler Library Periodical Holdings by Decade
           </strong>
           (reference desk) to find out what the library has from a particular time period.
           <br />
           <br />
           Trexler Library subscribes to the online index&nbsp;
           <strong>
            19th Century Masterfile
           </strong>
           , found at
           <a href="http://trexler.muhlenberg.edu/">
            <strong>
             Trexler Library Home Page
            </strong>
           </a>
           <em>
            &gt; Databases A to Z .&nbsp;
           </em>
           This index covers the New York Times and several magazines, all from the 19th century, many of which Trexler Library has full text in its print and microfilm collections.
           <br />
           <br />
           Magazines from earlier times have on occasion been scanned and loaded onto the web, as they have been at Cornell University's
           <a href="http://cdl.library.cornell.edu/moa/">
            <strong>
             Making of America
            </strong>
           </a>
           . Use in conjunction with a print index, such as the aforementioned
           <em>
            Poole's
           </em>
           or the
           <em>
            Reader's Guide
           </em>
           .
          </p>
          <div id="boxatt16949515" class="boxatt">
           <div class="itemlist">
            <ul>
            </ul>
            &nbsp;&nbsp;
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div id="wrapbox16949533">
        <div class="roundbox outerbox" id="16949533">
         <div class="roundbox headerbox" id="title16949533">
          <div class="bi_links">
           &nbsp;
          </div>
          <h2>
           Government documents as primary source material
          </h2>
         </div>
         <div class="roundbox innerbox innerbox_3" id="content16949533">
          <p>
           Trexler Library holds a wealth of government documents, in print, fiche, and online. Nearly all of these are listed in the
           <strong>
            Trexler Library Catalog
           </strong>
           (
           <a href="http://trexler.muhlenberg.edu/">
            <strong>
             Trexler Library Home Page
            </strong>
           </a>
           &nbsp;
           <em>
            &gt; Catalog
           </em>
           ).&nbsp; Search example: "hiv and history."
          </p>
          <div id="boxatt16949533" class="boxatt">
           <div class="itemlist">
            <ul>
            </ul>
            &nbsp;&nbsp;
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div id="wrapbox16949602">
        <div class="roundbox outerbox" id="16949602">
         <div class="roundbox headerbox" id="title16949602">
          <div class="bi_links">
           &nbsp;
          </div>
          <h2>
           Journal articles as secondary sources
          </h2>
         </div>
         <div class="roundbox innerbox innerbox_3" id="content16949602">
          <p>
           A reliable online index for scholarly journal articles and books dealing with medical history is the
           <em>
            History of Medicine
           </em>
           portion of
           <a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/advanced">
            <strong>
             PubMed
            </strong>
           </a>
           , a database from the National Library of Medicine. To use, limit to subsets: "History of Medicine."
           <br />
           The items indexed in this database can then be ordered through
           <a href="http://library.muhlenberg.edu/screens/illmain.html">
            <strong>
             Interlibrary Loan
            </strong>
           </a>
           , (path:&nbsp;
           <a href="http://trexler.muhlenberg.edu/">
            <strong>
             Trexler Library Home Page
            </strong>
           </a>
           <em>
            &gt; Interlibrary Loan
           </em>
           ).
           <br />
           <br />
           Use of the PubMed database is facilitated by the National Library of Medicine's
           <a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/mesh/MBrowser.html">
            <strong>
             Medical Subject Headings Guide
            </strong>
           </a>
           . Use this guide to look for subject headings on your topic. Try a search on "epidemics," for example.
           <br />
           <br />
           Another choice for more current history, say of AIDS/HIV, is the U.S. Government's
           <a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/">
            <strong>
             Medline Plus
            </strong>
           </a>
           , which indexes publications from the National Institutes of Health and the Center for Disease Control and Prevention.
           <br />
           <br />
           Trexler Library subscribes to several online indexes that are particularly useful for finding scholarly journals and book chapters on environmental history.&nbsp; These indexes, some with full text, can be found by following the path
           <a href="http://trexler.muhlenberg.edu/">
            <strong>
             Trexler Library Home Page
            </strong>
           </a>
           &nbsp;
           <em>
            &gt; Databases A to Z.
           </em>
           <em>
            &nbsp;
           </em>
           One reliable online index for scholarly journal articles and books dealing with medical history is the
           <strong>
            America History and Life
           </strong>
           database.&nbsp;&nbsp;Another resource likely to be useful is&nbsp; the standard index to social science journals,
           <strong>
            SocAbs
           </strong>
           .&nbsp; See also
           <strong>
            Academic Search Complete
           </strong>
           and
           <strong>
            Health Source
           </strong>
           .
          </p>
          <div id="boxatt16949602" class="boxatt">
           <div class="itemlist">
            <ul>
            </ul>
            &nbsp;&nbsp;
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div id="wrapbox16949743">
        <div class="roundbox outerbox" id="16949743">
         <div class="roundbox headerbox" id="title16949743">
          <div class="bi_links">
           &nbsp;
          </div>
          <h2>
           Books as secondary sources
          </h2>
         </div>
         <div class="roundbox innerbox innerbox_3" id="content16949743">
          <p>
           The
           <strong>
            Trexler Library Catalog
           </strong>
           (path:
           <a href="http://trexler.muhlenberg.edu/">
            <strong>
             Trexler Library Home Page
            </strong>
           </a>
           <strong>
           </strong>
           <em>
            &gt; Catalog
           </em>
           ) can prove useful for medical history topics. Try a keyWORD search to bring up all records on a particular topic, or to combine terms. Example: "disease and american."
          </p>
          <p>
           To expand your book search considerably, try
           <strong>
            WorldCat
           </strong>
           ; follow the path
           <a href="http://trexler.muhlenberg.edu/">
            <strong>
             Trexler Library Home Page
            </strong>
           </a>
           <em>
            &gt; Library Catalogs
           </em>
           . WorldCat is a powerful search tool for books on any subject. Use WorldCat in conjunction with
           <strong>
            Interlibrary Loan
           </strong>
           . From within WorldCat, click on the "ILL" icon that appears on any book record and fill out the required fields.
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
          <div id="boxatt16949743" class="boxatt">
           <div class="itemlist">
            <ul>
            </ul>
            &nbsp;&nbsp;
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div id="wrapbox16949888">
        <div class="roundbox outerbox" id="16949888">
         <div class="roundbox headerbox" id="title16949888">
          <div class="bi_links">
           &nbsp;
          </div>
          <h2>
           Secondary sources on the web
          </h2>
         </div>
         <div class="roundbox innerbox innerbox_3" id="content16949888">
          <p>
           Many web sites that provide secondary historical comment are in fact cursory in content, and scarcely documented. On the other hand,
           <em>
            scholarly sites
           </em>
           tend to be
           <br />
           --affiliated with an academic institution,
           <br />
           --offer content that has been published in print beforehand, and
           <br />
           --undergo peer review.
           <br />
           <br />
           One example of quality secondary resources on the web is the doctoral dissertation
           <a href="http://www.roizen.com/ron/disshome.htm">
            <strong>
             The American Discovery of Alcholism 1933-1939
            </strong>
           </a>
           .
          </p>
          <div id="boxatt16949888" class="boxatt">
           <div class="itemlist">
            <ul>
            </ul>
            &nbsp;&nbsp;
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div id="contentright" style="width:209px;float:left; padding-right:0px;">
      <div id="profile4610077" class="profile_wrapper">
      </div>
      <div id="rightboxes">
       <div id="wrapbox16949135">
        <div class="roundbox outerbox" id="16949135">
         <div class="roundbox headerbox" id="title16949135">
          <div class="bi_links">
           &nbsp;
          </div>
          <h2>
           Style guides
          </h2>
         </div>
         <div class="roundbox innerbox innerbox_3" id="content16949135">
          <p>
           For tips on citing print and electronic sources in a bibliography according to the Chicago (Turabian) style, follow the path
           <a href="http://trexler.muhlenberg.edu/">
            <strong>
             Trexler Library Home Page
            </strong>
           </a>
           (http://trexler.muhlenberg.edu/)
           <em>
            &gt; Citation Guides
           </em>
           .
          </p>
          <div id="boxatt16949135" class="boxatt">
           <div class="itemlist">
            <ul>
            </ul>
            &nbsp;&nbsp;
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div id="wrapbox16949584">
        <div class="roundbox outerbox" id="16949584">
         <div class="roundbox headerbox" id="title16949584">
          <div class="bi_links">
           &nbsp;
          </div>
          <h2>
           Finding statistics
          </h2>
         </div>
         <div class="roundbox innerbox innerbox_3" id="content16949584">
          <p>
           The subscription database
           <strong>
            <a href="http://0-hsus.cambridge.org.library.muhlenberg.edu/">
             Historical statistics of the United States
            </a>
           </strong>
           is the standard resource for all manner of statistics dating back to colonial times. Another option is the
           <strong>
            Statistical Abstracts of the United States
           </strong>
           , dating back to 1886 ( Govt Docs C 3.134:886).
           <br />
           <br />
           Or try
           <strong>
            Mortality Statistics
           </strong>
           and
           <strong>
            Vital Statistics of the United States
           </strong>
           , 1910 to present, (Govt. Docs HE 20.6210). See also
           <a href="http://fedstats.sites.usa.gov/">
            <strong>
             Fedstats
            </strong>
           </a>
           <strong>
            .
           </strong>
          </p>
          <div id="boxatt16949584" class="boxatt">
           <div class="itemlist">
            <ul>
            </ul>
            &nbsp;&nbsp;
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
    </div>
